perturbation.original_text: (d) Accounting Statement: Royalty statements (which statements shall be on the form attached hereto as Exhibit O and incorporated herein by this reference or such other form as the receiving party may designate in its discretion) shall be due and payments made within thirty (30) days after the close of each calendar quarter in which the paying party received any applicable revenue. Each party shall keep a record of all sales and shall submit, together with the royalty statements, a quarterly summary report of such sales.
perturbation.changed_text: (d) Accounting Statement: Royalty statements shall be due and payments made within ninety (90) days after the close of each calendar year in which the paying party received any applicable revenue. Each party shall keep a record of all sales and shall submit, together with the royalty statements, a yearly summary report of such sales.
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates royalty statements and payments quarterly, which is standard business practice. The modified text changes this to yearly statements and payments, 90 days after the close of each calendar year. This creates non-compliance as many jurisdictions and accounting standards require more frequent reporting and payment cycles to ensure transparency and timely remittance of royalties.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) and Sarbanes-Oxley Act requirements for financial reporting frequency.

perturbation.original_text: (e) Books and Records: Each party shall keep accurate and complete books and records as they relate hereto for the greater of three years from the Effective Date or two years from the termination or expiration of the Term. On reasonable notice, each party shall have the right to examine said books and records; provided that such examination will be made no more than twice in any given twelve month period, and shall be made during normal business hours. If any audit discloses that a party owes royalties in excess of 5% of royalties paid during any accounting period, the audited party shall pay the audit costs together with shortfall and interest at rates as specified in Paragraph 7(e) below.
perturbation.changed_text: (e) Books and Records: Each party shall keep accurate and complete books and records as they relate hereto for one year from the Effective Date. Each party shall have the right to examine said books and records only with a court order; provided that such examination will be made once after the one year deadline, and shall be made during normal business hours. If any audit discloses that a party owes royalties in excess of 20% of royalties paid during any accounting period, there is no recourse.
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires keeping books and records for the greater of three years from the effective date or two years from termination. This ensures sufficient time for audits and disputes. The modified text reduces this to one year, potentially violating statutes of limitations for breach of contract claims. The original text states there can be an audit done twice in any given twelve month period, the modified text creates an examination once after the one year deadline which does not comply with legal regulations for auditing.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Statutes of limitations for breach of contract (typically 4-6 years) and standard auditing practices.

perturbation.original_text: (h) Limitation of Actions: No legal action shall be brought by Licensee under this Agreement unless commenced within 12 months from the date the cause of action arose.
perturbation.changed_text: (h) Limitation of Actions: No legal action shall be brought by Licensee under this Agreement unless commenced within 6 months from the date the cause of action arose.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides a 12-month limitation period for legal actions. The modified text shortens this to 6 months. This is contradictory because the statute of limitations for contract disputes in California (where the agreement is governed) is typically much longer (e.g., four years).
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Code of Civil Procedure ยง 337 (four-year statute of limitations for written contracts).
